I had a fun time with How to Survive up until the final battle. Then I had to rage quit about 10 times before I finally lived through it.

-The narrative by Kovac keeps the mood fun and entertaining.
-There are a cool variety of monster types and weapons to build.
-The crafting system isn't overly burdensome although the few number of inventory slots made it a chore at times.
-I found the aiming to be a little inconsistent with a controller, especially for the boomerang which happened to be my favorite weapon.
-The story does end up to be a lot of fetch questing, which gets old fast.

14729215.review:
Another indie game that deserves recognition! How To Survive is similar to Diablo in the sense that you have the same isometric camera angle and you eliminate tons of enemies - this time, however, it's zombies instead of demons.

You can pick one from the available 3 protagonists - each has different strength and their skill tree is also different. Attributes change automatically - when levelling up after a set amount of XP you get to decide only which skill to pick.

Our heroes pretty soon meet Kovac, a mysterious fellow fully dressed in armor, who provides us with guidance as to how to survive. He explains eating, drinking, sleeping and the importance of - most of all - weapon crafting. There are dozens of items out there and they can be combined in various ways. When looting you'll bump into new guides regularly and these can be looked at from the menu.

I like how many types of foods could be made to quickly quell our hunger or thirst. A special fruit or root even eliminated our tiredness. Sleeping is only possible at select locations - these are shackles that must be rid of the walking dead before they can be entered. Not only sleeping but saving our progress is done at these locations. 

You find materials, you eliminate zombies, you pick up some herbs and fruits, you loot, free some locations, rinse and repeat. This is How to Survive in a nutshell. There are some side missions, extra difficulty levels and a separate challenge mode offering even more entertainment.

While an indie game How To Survive looks very decent. Once night falls new enemies appear who try to jump at you from behind. Your flashlight, however, provides the very source they are afraid of. This and fire are especially nice and I liked the fog effect, as well. The game employs some excellent physics effect, too. My favourite weapon from halfway through till the very end of the story was a boomerang I reinforced greatly with some bones and flint. Initially, however, melee will do along with a bow which you also get to make better and better.

In any case, I found How To Survive an entertaining experience. Too bad some difficulty levels (including new enemies and weather effects) and additional locations are only available in the form of DLCs. Make no mistake: if you liked it you'll probably pick them up, too, it's just a shame they have to rely on the same concept as some of the AAA developer companies do.

When discounted give How To Survive a try. But just the base game. And if you like Kovac and you accept his rules you can collect the DLCs, as well.

35556816.review:
This game is really about surviving.

At least, if you decide to play on the highest difficulty level. And, of course, it also depends on your skill. At the beginning of my time with this title, I was sometimes a bit frustrated because I did not know my way around. But after a while, I got hold of it, and then the game mechanics worked really well. Even on the hardest setting ("Kovac's Way"), I found enough resources to rather easily survive. Of course, I still died a lot because of the sometimes tough enemies (and of their sheer numbers, of course). This is expectable for such a title, I think, and I can hardly imagine anyone not dying quite regularly. Admittedly, I could have avoided many of these deaths if I used health boosters more often. I amassed them, and had about 100 of the poultices at the end. So, you see, you could use them fairly often (and much more often then I did). But even if you do not and die frequently, this is not too big an issue since you start at the last checkpoint with about 50% health. Here, I would have preferred the game always displayed when the progress is saved.
The presentation and graphics are very solid, and especially when the daytime and/or weather changes, the lighting effects are beautiful.
Occasionally, there have been some minor graphic bugs, and also sound issues. For example, the voice level of the characters was not always identical. Also, some design issues were noticeable, such as the presence of one NPC at two places simultaneously which was illogical, of course.
The controls are decent, and the two stick combination when using an Xbox 360 controller is rather nicely done. I would recommend using a controller instead of the keyboard and mouse combination, but it is obviously up to you to find out what works for you.
The story is also surprisingly good as it is intriguing and offers unexpected plot turns.
This game is much more about action than horror I think. So do not expect a really creepy exerience.
A very good point is also the playtime. I have spent around 50 hours to finish the storyline with just one of the characters, including all the DLC. 

All in all, apart from the minor problems, I give this title a 76 % rating.

49243283.review:
This is a rather short, yet entertaining zombie game. I have played the story mode, most of the DLC from the islands, the barricade mode and finally tried my luck in the one-shot-mode, just to be reminded how funny permadeath is.

+ decent amount of (adjustable) weapons and armor
+ collecting the consumables, weapon and armor parts shattered all over the islands is surprisingly motivating
+ many different enemies, some of which require different strategies to be defeated
~ there is a bit of story and it has some funny and creative moments. Could be more though. Just don't expect to play this game for the story :)
~ AI is weird. Usually the enemies act like braindead, but in close combat they become smart and try to flank you.
- no way to store your stuff. You can drop it on the ground and it will stay there till the end of time, but usually you'll want to keep most of the important stuff and half an armory in your backpack, in order to defeat certain enemies and combine stuff without extended periods of backtracking to where you dropped something.

42975166.review:
This is a fine survivor game which I found quite challenging at times.
The graphics is ok enough, though nothing special.
The sound and dialogs could have been better I think.
The game play  could also have been improved a bit I think. It at times feels a bit repetitive, at least for some quests.
Find 4, whatever and stuff.
And the UI should be easier to navigate in. It can be a bit annoying when wanting to see what you need from a blueprint, which isn't particularly descriptive either.
I wish it would have the possibility to assign items to direct keys instead of scrolling through the list of items / weapons you have. This can become annoying in fights.
Talking about items, as far as I know, there isn't a way to choose what you pick up if you've dropped a bunch of items on the ground, and they can even block doors for you. Nor is there any other storage besides your small inventory than just dropping items on the ground. This lead to a lot of frustration.
And to add to the list, you will get constantly hit by lightning when it rains, even in your safe house.
It's really quite amazing, and annoying.

Otherwise, I didn't encounter many glitches in the game. Some minor, like an enemy becoming invisible,
though this happened rarely. Then there were some times enemies got stuck in obstacles, which I didn't mind at all,
and a somewhat bugged death animation at times, with torsos floating in mid air.

With all this, you'd think I'd give this a thumbs down, but it really isn't that bad,
though I would recommend getting it on sale.

55068288.review:
How to survive? This is the question! And the answer is... backtracking!
What? No?
Then this game is not for you.

Go there, kill zombies on your way there, bring something back (while killing zombies), repeat.
In the meantime craft some weapons/food/gear. Crafting is quite nice - but nothing too complex. Also you will never have real problem with thirst or hunger - resources are everywhere and they are respawning (except weapon parts).
Plot is almost non existant - but lets be honest - nobody cares about that in that type of game.
Some bugs here and there - nothing gamebreaking, just cosmetic stuff (like zombie cut in half still standing in 2 parts that forgot to fall to the ground).

Challenges are quite fun - especially if you are aiming for corresponding achievements.

And obviously - co-op.

I can recommend to play it in small doses. It's great if you want to have some mindless fun after hard day.
Can't recommend it for full price though - there is not enough content for that (and game seems to be longer just because of backtracking).

8956649.review:
[b]You are shipwrecked on an isolated island, a desperate castaway in a total freakshow world.[/b]

[b]How will you survive?[/b]

Yes, how will you survive this mediocre "action-survival" game, a game which we've seen one too many times?

How to Survive plays like a isometric action-survival game (think of Diablo mixed with some minor elements from Don't Starve). 

Basically you run around, collect stuff you find while you mow down zombies with the collected stuff you've crafter. Usually with a rusty machete, chainsaw, an axe, a boomerang or some makeshift gun which looks more like a vacuum cleaner than a deadly weapon.

Let's just get it out of the way, the combat is extremely boring. It's boring, tedious and lackluster, and when you got thousands upon thousands of zombies chasing you then you'll get bored relatively fast. The developers also added a finish-move/take-down mechanic when the enemies health drops too low, but even that function is in most cased an hindrance for you to use.

The difficulty is also laughable. On the games website it says:  [b]"Try the “Iron Man” difficulty for a demanding hardcore game experience.[/b] 
Calling the Iron Man difficulty a hardcore experience is an insult to people who crave hard games. I died a few times because of my own stupidity (I used the take-down move and it got me surrounded), but other than that the Iron Man mode is a walk in the park. I never had any problem finding ammo, food, water or shelter.

There isn't a lot of "surviving" to do in this game, the crafting is tedious and the items you can craft are very limited. Craft yourself a triple bladed boomerang (with spikes) as soon as possible (on the second island) and you'll never want to use another weapon ever again.
Ammo, food, water and shelter can be found everywhere, it basically becomes a chore to survive, and that chore isn't even remotely fun.

The game also suffers from being ridden with bugs and is also terribly unoptimized. When you got an almost new computer with an i7 processor, 16gb ram and a 2gb memory card which has problems to render the water properly, then you know the developers were pretty lazy.

I wouldn't recommend this game, not by a long shot. It's simply not worth your time or your money.
